2. Coarse-graining the tensor network iteratively until it converges to a fixed point.

4. Diagonalize the transfer matrix to find its eigenvalues.

prompt: We are interested in counting fully packed dimer configurations on honeycomb lattice. Dimer can be placed on any of the nearest-neighbor bonds of the lattice and each site has to be a member of exactly one dimer. This is one of the ways to count ground state configurations of classical antiferromagnetic Ising model on triangular lattice. In particular, we want to consider a horizontal cylinder geometry, with the periodic boundary condition in vertical direction and zig-zag open edges. Here is an example of such geometry, given as an illustration in LateX's verbatim environment \begin{verbatim} \ / \ / A--B A--B / \ / \ B A--B A \ / \ / A--B A--B / \ / \ B A--B A \ / \ / A--B A--B / \ / \ B A--B A \end{verbatim} This is an XC-6 cylinder with width W=6, W being the number of sites in the vertical direction, and length L=3, again L being the number of honeycomb lattice unit cells in the horizontal direction. Let's call the number of "empty" sites divided by the total number of sites on the edge the "defect density". Answer following two questions. First, In the limit of wide cylinders, what defect density leads to the highest number of packed dimer configurations ? Second, for XC-11 cylinder, what is the defect density which gives the second highest number of packed dimer configurations ? Return your answer as two numbers, separated by a comma, in $\boxed{}$ environment, rounded to 2 decimal places Your final solution must be placed in a $\boxed{}$ LaTeX environment. Use only the variables and constants given in the problem; do not define additional constants.
